snippet: China still considers itself a developing country for purposes of climate negotiations, even as raising funds to help poorer countries remains a hurdle for the talks.
abstract: Economically ascendant China is reluctant to give up developing nation designation amid push to finance fight against global warming; Western negotiators search for compromise which will secure Chinese contribution to $100 billion annual target, while allowing it to avoid industrialized nation status, which would impose more stringent emissions regulations.

byline.original: By KEITH BRADSHER and CORAL DAVENPORT
byline.contributor: Keith Bradsher reported from Paris, and Coral Davenport from Le Bourget, France. Sewell Chan contributed reporting from Le Bourget.

lead_paragraph: China still considers itself a developing country for purposes of climate negotiations, even as raising funds to help poorer countries remains a hurdle for the talks.

headline.main: As U.S. and Europe Pass the Hat at Climate Talks, China Clings to Developing-Nation Status
headline.print_headline: As West Passes Hat at Climate Talks, China Clings to Developing-Nation Status

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
